name: Velocity Layers Showcase
description: Demonstrates the new velocity layers in sampled instruments. Notice how timbre changes with dynamics - soft notes sound different from loud notes, not just quieter.

tracks.name: Grand Piano - Dynamic Expression
tracks._comment: 3 velocity layers (pp/mf/ff) - soft notes have rounder tone, loud notes have brighter attack

tracks.name: Rhodes EP - Jazz Dynamics
tracks._comment: 3 velocity layers - electric piano bark increases with velocity

tracks.name: Steel Drums - Mallet Intensity
tracks._comment: 3 velocity layers (soft/medium/hard) - brightness increases with mallet force

tracks.name: Crash Cymbal - Impact Variation
tracks._comment: 3 velocity layers - soft crashes have less high-frequency content

tracks.name: Brush Snare - Tap to Accent
tracks._comment: 3 velocity layers (tap/hit/hard) - brush response from gentle to accented

listenFor: Piano: Soft notes (pp) have rounder, warmer tone; loud notes (ff) have brighter attack with more harmonics
Rhodes: Gentle playing is smooth and warm; harder playing brings out the classic 'bark'
Steel Drums: Soft mallets produce mellow tone; hard strikes have bright shimmer
Crash: Soft crash has less splash; loud crash has full frequency spectrum
Brushes: Light taps vs accented hits show different brush character
whyItMatters: Velocity layers transform mechanical sequences into expressive performances. Real instruments don't just get louder - they change character. These samples capture that dynamic expression.
